item.title: Dealing with mental health as a Developer
item.description: We need to talk about mental health as a developer.
item.content:encoded:
Hey everyone! â¤ï¸âœ¨

Being a developer means dealing with a lotâ€”balancing life, managing clients, keeping up with the fast evolution of IT, surviving in a hyper-competitive world, and racing to build your career. Itâ€™s a lot to handle, and today, I want to talk about whatâ€™s usually left unsaid.

The Hidden Depressionâ€‹

I started my career at 20. Looking back, I was really young when I first entered the corporate world and realized how tough it can be. I struggled a lot to find my place as a developerâ€”and being a woman added a whole other layer of challenge (but thatâ€™s a topic for another post). I pushed myself to learn what I could, to be better every single day, until I hit burnout at 23.

During that period, I didnâ€™t know how to take care of myself. I kept comparing my journey and skills to others, constantly feeling like I wasnâ€™t good enough. I would cry every day in the bathroom at work if I made a mistake or didnâ€™t meet expectations. The worst part? The pressure was all coming from insideâ€”I just didnâ€™t know how to deal with it.

It got even worse. I watched people around me get promoted or recognized, while I felt invisible. â€œWhatâ€™s wrong with me? Why am I not like them?â€ I asked myself over and over. I kept chasing improvement, but no matter how much I tried, I felt like Iâ€™d never be that standout developerâ€”the one whoâ€™s different, better, the reference for others. Three years into my career, thatâ€™s how I felt.

Honestly, sometimes I still do. Every time I open LinkedIn, attend a conference, or talk to other developers, I question if Iâ€™m enough. When the industry starts hyping a new technology, I panic: â€œHow am I supposed to learn everything, fast? How will I meet expectations? Where do I even start?â€

If I donâ€™t have experience with a certain technologyâ€”one I never even had the chance to work withâ€”I feel like Iâ€™m failing at â€œbeing that amazing, senior, all-knowing developer whoâ€™s a role model no matter the company.â€

Even after years of therapy, these feelings still pop up. Itâ€™s tough to deal with them every single day. Thatâ€™s the hidden depression for me. Everyone tries to look perfect (and maybe they are), while I feel like Iâ€™ll never measure up. Tech is an amazing, exciting world, but it can also be lonely, overwhelming, and sometimes, deeply painful.

The Light at the End of the Tunnelâ€‹

But not all is lost. We donâ€™t have to feel this way forever, or accept that this is just how our lives will be. So I want to share some things that have helped me get through the hard times.

1. Therapy, Therapy, and More Therapyâ€‹

Never underestimate the power of speaking to a professional. Therapy helped me understand my patterns, where my feelings came from, and how to build healthier ways of coping. Most importantly, I learned my worth isnâ€™t tied to my job title or achievements.

I found that talking to someone who can guide you through your journeyâ€”who helps you understand how you got to this placeâ€”can completely change the game. But Iâ€™ll be honest: it isnâ€™t easy, like people sometimes make it sound online. Facing memories and realities in your own little (but huge) world takes real courage. Still, as someone whoâ€™s been there, I promise you can take a step forward and learn to deal with these feelings so they donâ€™t stop your life.

I know talking about mental health is â€œcoolâ€ on the internet, but in real life Iâ€™ve had to deal with people saying things like, â€œWhy do you need that? You were raised in church, just pray and itâ€™ll go away,â€ or â€œAre you going crazy? Is that why you need a doctor?â€ or â€œIf you just ignore it, it goes away.â€ Unfortunately, a lot of people still think like that. But hereâ€™s my advice, friend to friend: ignore those voices. Focus on caring for yourself and asking for help. It changed my lifeâ€”it can change yours too.

2. Take Medication If You Need Itâ€‹

Thereâ€™s no shame in seeking medical help if you need it. Sometimes our minds need the same care weâ€™d give to a broken bone or any other illness. Medicationâ€”when prescribed by a professionalâ€”can be a crucial part of healing, and thatâ€™s okay.

I know taking medication can be scary; trust me, I felt that fear and dealt with all the stigma that comes with itâ€”especially around medication for depression, anxiety, bipolar disorder, and so on. Not everyone needs it, but in my case, it was necessary. When I started, my life changed. Before that, I couldnâ€™t study, eat, or even take care of my basic hygiene because of all the anxiety and sadness I felt. Iâ€™d only shower to go to work, then come home and sleep until the next day. It was a really hard period, and I made it through with medical help.

But I also have to sayâ€”taking medication alone isnâ€™t enough. If you donâ€™t also address the root cause in therapy, you wonâ€™t really get better. Medication can help stabilize things, but therapy helps you heal. So if you need it, take your medication with professional guidanceâ€”and donâ€™t give up on the process.

3. Share How Youâ€™re Feeling With People You Trustâ€‹

Open up to friends, family, or even colleagues you feel safe with. Youâ€™d be surprised how many people have similar feelings but are just afraid to speak up. You are not alone, and letting others in can make a world of difference.

Support from people you trust is crucial in those dark timesâ€”it really does change everything. A few years ago, when I tried to end my life, what stopped me after the third attempt was finally asking for help. That help turned everything around, and Iâ€™m here today because of it.

4. Start Smallâ€”One Thing at a Timeâ€‹

You donâ€™t need to change your whole life overnight. Celebrate small winsâ€”learning a new thing, finishing a task, or even just taking a break when you need it. Progress is progress, no matter the size.

This was honestly the hardest thing for me to understand and put into practice. Starting simple and completing small tasks to build real progressâ€”but once I began, I started seeing results and learning more effectively. I realized thereâ€™s no point trying to learn everything at once. Focus on something, but donâ€™t forget to live and rest. Learning is important, but if you push too hard and burn out, itâ€™s not worth it.

Remember: You Are Enoughâ€‹

You donâ€™t have to be perfect. You donâ€™t have to know every new technology or be everyoneâ€™s role model. All you need is to care for yourself and move forward at your own pace.

If youâ€™re struggling right now, please remember: youâ€™re not alone, and things can get better. The tech world can be hard, but it can also be full of kindness and supportâ€”sometimes, you just have to ask for it.

Letâ€™s talk more openly about mental health. We all have our own battles, but together, we can make the journey lighter.

And if you ever want to share your storyâ€”or just need someone to listenâ€”my inbox is always open. ğŸ’™

item.title: Fun Python Tips & Curious Facts Every Developer Should Know
item.description: Some Python tips and fun facts to make your coding journey more interesting!
item.content:encoded:
Hey everyone! ğŸâœ¨

Python isnâ€™t just a programming language â€” itâ€™s a whole vibe. Whether youâ€™re just starting out, or already writing scripts before your morning tea (yep, I know â€” sorry, developer community, I donâ€™t drink coffee!), thereâ€™s always something new (or quirky!) to learn. So here are some fun Python facts and tips to brighten your dev day:

The Zen of Pythonâ€‹

Did you know Python comes with its own â€œphilosophy poemâ€? Just open your terminal and type:

import this

Youâ€™ll get the Zen of Pythonâ€”19 guiding aphorisms by Tim Peters, like:

  • â€œBeautiful is better than ugly.â€
  • â€œSimple is better than complex.â€
  • â€œReadability counts.â€

Trust me, if you havenâ€™t seen it, itâ€™s worth a look. Itâ€™s like a fortune cookie for developers. ğŸ

Naming Your Python Files: camelCase or snake_case?â€‹

Spoiler alert: In Python, the PEP8 style guide recommends using snake_case (lowercase with underscores) for filenames and function namesâ€”like my_awesome_script.py.

Butâ€¦ what happens if you use camelCase, like myAwesomeScript.py?

Technically, your script will still work, and you can even import it using the same name. But if you ever share your code, or move between Windows and Linux, you might run into confusing import errors (since Linux treats uppercase and lowercase as different files). Plus, Python tools and most developers expect snake_case for file and module namesâ€”so using camelCase can lead to warnings, headaches, and harder-to-maintain code.

Save yourself (and your team) some future troubleâ€”stick to snake_case for filenames and module names. Your future self will thank you! ğŸ˜‰

Why is it Called Python?â€‹

No, itâ€™s not named after the snake! Guido van Rossum, Pythonâ€™s creator, named it after the British comedy group â€œMonty Pythonâ€™s Flying Circus.â€ So, itâ€™s not uncommon to see official docs and tutorials full of jokes and silly references. Next time you see a variable called spam or eggsâ€”now you know why!

Bonus Tips to Power Up Your Pythonâ€‹

F-strings make formatting a breeze:â€‹

Instead of "Hello, {}".format(name) use f"Hello, {name}".

List comprehensions save time:â€‹

[x*x for x in range(10)] One line, super readable.

Want to see all built-in functions?â€‹

Try dir(__builtins__) in the REPL.

Use virtual environments:â€‹

Run python -m venv venv to keep your project dependencies isolated (and your global Python happy).

Multiple variable assignment:â€‹

You can assign several variables at once: a, b, c = 1, 2, 3

Clean and â€œpythonicâ€!âœ¨

Swap variables in one line:â€‹

No need for a temporary variable: a, b = b, a

The â€œelseâ€ in loops:â€‹

You can use else with a for or while loop! The else block runs only if the loop wasnâ€™t interrupted by a break.

for n in range(5):
    if n == 3:
        print("Found 3!")
        break
else:
    print("3 not found!")

Underscore (_) for ignoring values:â€‹

Donâ€™t care about a value in an assignment or loop? Use _ as a placeholder:
for _, value in enumerate(my_list):

Get the index and value in a loop:â€‹

Use enumerate() for easy indexing:

for index, value in enumerate(['a', 'b', 'c']):
    print(index, value)

Use join() to concatenate strings in a list:â€‹

words = ["Hello", "world"]
sentence = " ".join(words)  # Output: "Hello world"

Quickly reverse a list:â€‹

my_list[::-1]

Docs, PEPs & the Awesome Python Communityâ€‹

  • Official Docs Are Your Best Friend: The official Python documentation is clear, detailed, and full of examples. Whenever youâ€™re unsure about a function, module, or syntax, check the docs firstâ€”it will save you hours of guessing and Stack Overflow deep dives.

  • PEPs: Python Enhancement Proposals: Ever wondered how Python evolves? Through PEPs! These documents describe new features, improvements, and the philosophy of Python. The most famous one is PEP 8, which defines Pythonâ€™s style guide. Some other fun PEPs to check out:

    • PEP 20 â€“ The Zen of Python
    • PEP 257 â€“ Docstring Conventions
    • PEP 484 â€“ Type Hints

  • Write Great Docstrings: Good code tells a storyâ€”so help your future self (and your teammates) by writing clear docstrings for your functions, classes, and modules! Use triple quotes and follow PEP 257:

    def add(a, b):
        """
        Add two numbers and return the result.

        Args:
            a (int): First number.
            b (int): Second number.

        Returns:
            int: The sum of a and b.
        """
        return a + b

  • Python Community is Everywhere: Donâ€™t code alone!

    • Join Python Discord
    • Follow the r/learnpython subreddit
    • Attend local meetups or PyCon events
    • Or ask questions on Stack Overflowâ€”Pythonâ€™s community is famously friendly and helpful!

  • Contribute Back! Python thrives on open source and community contributions. Whether youâ€™re fixing a typo in the docs, adding a tutorial, or helping someone on a forum, youâ€™re already making Python better for everyone.

ğŸ§  One Last Curiosityâ€¦â€‹

The Zen of Python ends with:

â€œAlthough practicality beats purity.â€ So if you ever feel lost in style rules, remember: Itâ€™s better to write code that works (and that you understand), than to get stuck trying to be perfect.

item.title: What is a Large Language Model (LLM)?
item.description: A simple yet technical guide to understanding Large Language Models (LLMs) and how theyâ€™re reshaping the way we build products.
item.content:encoded:
Hey everyone! ğŸ’»âœ¨

Today I want to talk about something Iâ€™ve been working: Large Language Models (LLMs). If you've been hearing a lot about ChatGPT, Bard, Claude, or LLaMA and wondered what all the buzz is about â€” Iâ€™ve got you. Letâ€™s break it down in a clear and friendly way.

What Exactly Is a Large Language Model?â€‹

A Large Language Model is a type of artificial intelligence designed to understand and generate human language. Think of it as a super smart assistant thatâ€™s read massive amounts of data â€” books, articles, code, forum posts, and even images or videos â€” and now knows how to generate coherent and useful text responses. ğŸ¤¯

They're called "large" because they contain billions (and sometimes trillions!) of parameters â€” which are essentially learned settings that help the model detect patterns in language.

How Are LLMs Created?â€‹

Everything starts with training â€” and hereâ€™s where things get a little technical, but in a good way.

At the core of most LLMs is a deep learning architecture called the Transformer, introduced by Google in 2017. (For the curious minds, hereâ€™s the original â€œAttention Is All You Needâ€ paper.) This architecture revolutionized the way we work with language in AI by making it possible to model relationships between words over long distances in a text.

Rather than analyzing words one at a time, Transformers allow the model to understand entire sequences at once â€” similar to how you read a message and instantly understands its meaning, even without emojis or GIFs. ğŸ’¬

Tools That Power LLM Developmentâ€‹

Most LLMs are developed using Python, alongside popular deep learning libraries like:

  • PyTorch â€“ widely used in research and production
  • TensorFlow â€“ known for its scalability and performance
  • JAX â€“ favored by Google for high-performance model training

These frameworks help build the modelâ€™s internal architecture, which includes:

  • Embedding layers â€“ turn words into vector representations the model can process
  • Multi-head self-attention â€“ lets the model "pay attention" to all words in a sentence at once
  • Feed-forward neural networks â€“ deepen the understanding of context
  • Layer normalization and residual connections â€“ stabilize the learning process

These components are stacked dozens of times (up to 96 layers in models like GPT-4), resulting in deep networks with massive capacity for language understanding.

How Do LLMs Actually Learn?â€‹

LLMs are trained using self-supervised learning, which means they learn by predicting words in vast amounts of unlabeled text.

There are two common objectives:

  • Causal Language Modeling (CLM) â€“ Predict the next word in a sentence (e.g., GPT)
  • Masked Language Modeling (MLM) â€“ Predict missing words in a sentence (e.g., BERT)

To learn, the model uses:

  • Backpropagation â€“ a mathematical technique for adjusting internal parameters based on mistakes
  • Gradient descent â€“ an optimization method that helps the model improve gradually with each example

With time and repetition, the model becomes excellent at predicting what comes next in a sentence â€” which is exactly what allows it to write stories, generate code, answer questions, and so much more.

Training at Scale: A Super Brain Goes To the Gymâ€‹

Training an LLM is like sending a super-brain to bootcamp â€” lifting data instead of weights â€” for weeks or even months.

It requires:

  • Hardware: Hundreds to thousands of GPUs (e.g., NVIDIA A100s) or TPUs

  • Data: Terabytes of curated text â€” books, articles, forums, code repositories, etc.

  • Optimization techniques:

    • Mixed precision training (for memory efficiency)
    • Gradient checkpointing (to reduce memory usage)
    • Data/model parallelism (to spread the workload across multiple devices)

What Happens After Training?â€‹

Once the model is trained, it can be:

  • Fine-tuned for specific domains (e.g., healthcare, law, customer support)
  • Aligned with human values using Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF) â€” the secret sauce behind ChatGPTâ€™s natural tone

Where Are LLMs Being Used?â€‹

Everywhere! Some real-world applications include:

  • Chatbots and virtual assistants (like ChatGPT, Bard, Copilot)
  • Internal knowledge bases and customer support tools
  • Coding assistants (GitHub Copilot, Cody, etc.)
  • Business intelligence (summarizing reports, extracting insights)
  • Education (tutoring, quiz generation)
  • Marketing & eCommerce (product descriptions, reviews, emails)

How Developers Use LLMs Every Dayâ€‹

LLMs are easier to integrate than ever â€” hereâ€™s how devs can use them right now:

1. OpenAI GPT (ChatGPT)â€‹

Use the OpenAI API to add gpt-4 or gpt-3.5-turbo to your apps.

Use cases: Chatbots, AI helpdesks, content generation, code explanation, test generation.

2. Google PaLM 2 / Geminiâ€‹

Google Cloudâ€™s Vertex AI supports powerful LLMs for enterprise apps.

Use cases: Multimodal apps, enterprise search, document analysis.

3. Anthropic Claudeâ€‹

Claude is known for its thoughtful responses and safe design. Great for structured Q&A and summarization.

4. Meta LLaMA (Open Source)â€‹

Metaâ€™s LLaMA models are open-source and ideal for:

  • Privacy-first apps â€“ Your users' data stays with you
  • On-device AI â€“ No internet? No problem
  • Lightweight experimentation â€“ Great for prototyping without cloud costs

5. Hugging Face Transformersâ€‹

The ultimate playground for developers and researchers. HuggingFace Transformers lets you load and test LLMs like GPT, T5, BERT, and more:

pip install transformers
from transformers import pipeline

generator = pipeline("text-generation", model="gpt2")
print(generator("Once upon a time,", max_length=50))

LLMs in Products: Real Examplesâ€‹

  • E-commerce: Smart descriptions, review summaries, product Q&A
  • EdTech: Lesson planners, tutoring, content feedback
  • Healthcare: Summarizing notes, answering medical FAQs (responsibly)
  • Business: Analyzing emails, reports, and meeting summaries

â¤ï¸ Final Thoughtsâ€‹

Weâ€™re only scratching the surface of what LLMs can do. As developers, product builders, and creators, weâ€™re in a moment of incredible opportunity.

âœ¨ Start small â€” test an API, build a chatbot, experiment with a prompt. Youâ€™ll be surprised how far your creativity can take you with these tools at your side.

Useful Links Recapâ€‹

  • OpenAI GPT API Docs
  • HuggingFace Transformers
  • Google Vertex AI
  • Anthropic Claude
  • Meta LLaMA
  • â€œAttention is All You Needâ€ (original paper)
  • Large language model â€“ Wikipedia

item.title: My Experience at TheDevConf 2025
item.description: Itâ€™s been about 9 months since I started working on developing solutions using artificial intelligence â€” with a particular focus on generative AI. In recognition of my contributions, my company awarded me the opportunity to attend TDC â€” The Developer Conference AI, that happen in SÃ£o Paulo, Brazil.
item.content:encoded:
Itâ€™s been about 9 months since I started working on developing solutions using artificial intelligence â€” with a particular focus on generative AI. In recognition of my contributions, my company awarded me the opportunity to attend TDC â€” The Developer Conference AI, that happen in SÃ£o Paulo, Brazil.

This conference is aimed at developers connecting with each other, discovering new trends, discussing best practices, sharing knowledge, etc. It was my first time attending a conference, and honestly, I felt like Sheldon! ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚

Iâ€™m someone who, on the surface, seems sociable, but I hate being in large crowds and never really got excited about these types of events. I always thought they were overrated. I donâ€™t even believe in astrology, but Iâ€™ll blame it on my sign today hahahaha.

The conference took place on March 26th and 27th, 2025, and it focused on artificial intelligence. There were several panels covering various topics related to generative AI. In general, the panels discussed how AI is being applied in different areas like healthcare, agriculture, software development, everyday life, and more. And Iâ€™d love to share some of the themes that impacted me the most.

The first panel that really struck me was from a company that uses AI to monitor neonatal ICUs. Through the electrodes placed on the babies, data is collected and analyzed in real time by a system using generative AI. The case presented involved a newborn with complications. When the baby started having significant changes that required medical intervention, the system had already identified the issue hours in advance â€” the baby was having an epileptic seizure. With this analysis, doctors were able to act quickly, and the baby survived. In fact, the baby is now healthy and growing well, under medical supervision of course. Incredible, right? I was deeply moved by this case!

The second impactful panel was about the use of generative AI in agriculture. They showed how AI is transforming the industry through soil, weather, and livestock analysis... The presenter even showed AI-powered cameras being used for these analyses, for example. One thing I was curious about was the stereotype that people in agriculture are resistant to technology. The speaker explained that the new generation in agribusiness is much more open to using technology in their daily work, and even many from older generations understand its importance now. It was really cool!!

The third panel that impressed me was a presentation by a team working on modernizing legacy code. With the help of generative AI, a parte of the code that was expected to take a year to be complete, actually took 6 months. Amazing, right? Thatâ€™s a huge time savings!

What I enjoyed most about the talks I participated, was that the speakers emphasized the importance of using AI consciously and responsibly. And this goes way beyond just using AI for anythingâ€”itâ€™s about knowing why youâ€™re using it, applying prompt engineering to get accurate responses, validating whether the AI's response is correct, checking if itâ€™s "hallucinating," and so on. Not to mention the environmental impact of AI usage, which is a real can of wormsâ€”girl, itâ€™s scary!

This conference was amazing! I had so much fun, learned a lot, and met some incredible professionals! For example, I participated in a mentorship focused on working on international projects, which is exactly the direction I want my career to go right now. I absolutely loved it and I think the experience is totally worth it!

Negative points:

  • The location wasnâ€™t great, and there werenâ€™t any nearby restaurants to have lunch without a long walkâ€”which I didnâ€™t love.
  • The food experience was poor. The event had announced that there would be partner food vendors, but in the end, there werenâ€™t any. There was a communication failure, which was a big deal since I spent the whole day there. Especially because I was alone and didnâ€™t feel safe walking around that part of SÃ£o Paulo on my own.

Positive points:

  • The venue itself was really nice.
  • I got a bunch of free goodies, which was super fun!

  • The "silent presentation" format was the coolest part: basically, three panels were happening at the same time. We wore headphones and could switch stations at any time to follow whichever presentation we wanted.
  • I really enjoyed the networking, the spaces, the mentoring sessions, and the companies that were there!

All in all, it was absolutely worth it!

item.title: 6 Months in an Innovation Lab
item.description: Six months ago, I started working on an innovation project. The main idea of this project is to test innovative solutions for problems using Generative AI. It's been a completely new world for me, as until then, I had only worked on product delivery. Working in this lab completely took me out of my bubble, especially because I am a backend engineer. During this period, I've learned a few things:
item.content:encoded:
Six months ago, I started working on an innovation project. The main idea of this project is to test innovative solutions for problems using Generative AI. It's been a completely new world for me, as until then, I had only worked on product delivery. Working in this lab completely took me out of my bubble, especially because I am a backend engineer. During this period, I've learned a few things:

Not Everything Can Be Solved with Generative AIâ€‹

The tech world is as crazy as the release of a new pop diva's album. The revolution of some emerging technologies makes many people in the market, especially business leaders, rush to implement these solutions at any cost. When a pop diva releases an iconic album, it's literally written in the stars that all brands, trends, and even the fashion industry will ride that wave. The same happens in technology: when truly impactful innovation arises, everyone wants to adopt, adapt, and capitalize on it. The problem is that, often, this rush happens without a real understanding of whether that tool is truly the right solution for the problem.

What I love most about this project is that it forces me to think outside of my bubble and even question whether the solution Iâ€™m proposing really makes sense for the business problem weâ€™re solving or if Generative AI meets our expectations. Not every problem needs Generative AI to be solved, but the fact that we reflect on the effectiveness of these technologies in our challenges completely changes the idea of "just using technology at any cost."

Best Practices and Automation, Yes, Always!â€‹

In this project, we deliver rapid prototypes. Therefore, we are constantly testing new solutions and making them available for evaluation. The fact that we deliver only prototypes does not mean that software best practices should be neglected. Iâ€™ve felt firsthand how important it is to apply good development practices and have automated deployment in all projects.

Using new technology doesnâ€™t mean we need to abandon best practices or leave them only partially structured. They exist for a good reason: to make the developer's life easier and increase delivery speed. It has been very satisfying to see the greatness of these practices applied in my daily work, especially aligned with Generative AI, which means that a new technology should not override everything else. I love software best practices, and once you work by following this model, you don't want to do things any other way.

The Exponential Power of Generative AIâ€‹

During this time, I had the chance to use some Generative AI models for our deliveries, and itâ€™s fascinating to see the exponential power of these technologies. One of the most striking models was OpenAIâ€™s embedding model, as well as the model for working with voice.

At one point, I had to work with RAG on a vector database, combined with an embedding model. It was soo cool to see the program's behavior when returning data based on search similarity, everything felt magical! But if thereâ€™s no good database foundation, things can backfire. Also, some libraries can be heavy in Python, so if you donâ€™t have a machine that can handle it, you might end up with some headaches.

In my experience, I used chromadb as a vector database, and wow, that was a sentimental little database. Just one wrong configuration, and it doesn't work properly. At the time, I had to deploy it on AWS, and even though I configured communication ports for it to access the internet, it would pick any port except the one we wanted, and that was a pain! But for small tests, it behaved well, which makes me excited about the possibilities. Iâ€™m currently exploring other vector databases, but it was really cool to learn from chromadb. I didnâ€™t know the concepts too deeply, but it was super interesting to work with.

What saved me many times was the fact that I had a powerful machine to work with. Iâ€™ve crashed my PC about 4 times in a row testing some extremely heavy models and libraries, but my machine survived. Even working with AWS Lambda or EC2, the process of using the libraries can be slow depending on the installation process, and Docker was our ally in that fight. One thing that makes me reflect on Gen AI is the fact that we need to have a decent machine to work with some libraries and models, at least locally. At least in my experience, after we included Docker, it became much easier to work with these heavier libraries like langchain, a dream on a summer night, literally.

With the voice model, it was very interesting to notice the naturalness in the speech, especially with some accents, which really surprised me!! The model we tested for conversation flow had such a great tone that can be calibrated, which opens infinite possibilities for accessibility, and that's amazing!

Generative AI, when aligned correctly, is amazing and takes delivery standards to the next level! Iâ€™ve learned to be flexible in this regard, the ability to test different models, aligned with best practices, is out of this world.

Women in Power!â€‹

In this project, many amazing, intelligent, and supportive people have passed through. But Iâ€™m very proud to say that the team is mostly female. What a joy it is to work with other women, share experiencesâ€¦ I feel heard, welcomed, and embraced. A privilege!

These past few months have been great.
